Looks like an issue with your data not adhering to the csv format. As you can see from the logs, all the 640 rows were unparseable. Please double check your data and if you need further help, post a sample of the data that you're attempting to index.

@leventov / @jihoonson looks like some of the comments are unable to be responded to directly for some reason, maybe they are on a commit instead of the PR? I'll see if I can figure out what's goin on and get responses to them.

@drcrallen I left my comments on the PR and maybe it's because the lines corresponding to the comments have been updated by some following commits. In that case, github shows those comments twice: one is in the original place where the reviewer left. This is usually hidden because the lines corresponding to the comments have been updated. Another is visible in some random place.

> This could probably be fixed by plugging in a PasswordProvider implementation

I think that would work, you could adjust the consumerProperties and resolve the PasswordProviders in `getKafkaConsumer()`.

> or maybe reuse the keystore info from the druid.server.https.keyStorePassword property

I think the PasswordProvider or another mechanism would be better, there's no guarantee that the truststore needed for connecting to kafka would have the same password as the truststore/keystore used by Druid.
Makes sense. I'll work on getting a PR out for this.
Let me do more tests before merging this.

I'll change my vote to 0-. I'm not going veto the PR but I also see almost no benefit in it either.

@gianm any chance there's a way to get `git` to recognize these as renames instead of drops and adds?

As it stands, I don't think a merge from master would be tolerable for any outstanding PR as they would all just be klobbered
👍 after test, my browser crashes when loading pages...will have to trust @gianm on this one.

@drcrallen Git actually can figure out that these are renames, but you must change these configs first:

```
git config --local diff.renameLimit 5000
git config --local merge.renameLimit 5000
```

By default, git will disable rename detection if the number of files is >400 for diffs or >1000 for merges.

added labels for `ReleaseNotes` and `Compatibility` as this one will definitely break all extensions.

also users using monitors such as "io.druid.java.util.metrics.JvmMonitor" will need to change.

+1 after the successful build.
FYI, I put the steps I used here in the top comment. Parts (6) and (7) were just done now, I missed them in the first commit, and they resulted in some of the test failures.
Ah, @himanshug your comment makes me realize we should also update the migration code in MonitorsConfig. I'll do that now.

Interesting, there was a bump in CalciteQueryTest because some plans changed in cosmetic ways (dimensions in different order in cases where it doesn't really matter what the order is). I'm not sure why, maybe Calcite's planner went down different paths due to package name differences (possibly in toStrings)? Fixed that and pushed again.
We encounter this problem recently. Will kafka-indexing-service skip these data after some retries?
I verified response from `/db/{authenticatorName}/cachedSerializedUserMap` is deserializable. The root cause is BytesFullResponseHandler doesn't deal with ChannelBuffer correctly.

@xy-xin I think yes, although it is not super graceful (they will have to time out first). You could set `lateMessageRejectionPeriod` as a workaround until #5868 and #5869 are implemented (I think they are the ultimate right approach to this).
Added a fix for protobuf tests and re-pushed. The unit tests all pass on my machine, although I haven't tried the integration tests there. Will keep monitoring them in Travis.

Thanks for your reply, @gianm . Have confirmed the result, and nothing bad impact. But still looking forward to #5868  and #5869

You can rename the field at query time, like this:
```
{
  "type" : "default",
  "dimension" : <dimension>,
  "outputName": <output_name>,
  "outputType": <"STRING"|"LONG"|"FLOAT">
}
```
Yeah, I was about to open exactly the same PR ;-) 👍 .

Sorry for chiming in early, but is there any way to use this in a real (not just tests/benchmarks) scenario? I've tried "brute force" by modifying realtime/plumber/Sink to use OffheapOak, instead of the current Onheap default. But all that's happening is index Task spinning the CPU for a looong time and eventually going OOM.
I guess this is not the way it should be :-).
If this is just not ready for real world testing yet, that's fine. I just felt like giving it a spin.

This looks like a duplicate of https://github.com/apache/incubator-druid/issues/622. Can we close this issue in favour of that one?
This looks like a duplicate of https://github.com/apache/incubator-druid/issues/622. Can we close this issue in favour of that one?

These two configurations seem redundant to me and have always caused a lot of confusion. Could we get rid of one of them? 

I found two other issues suggesting to do so (https://github.com/apache/incubator-druid/issues/373 and https://github.com/apache/incubator-druid/issues/798), unfortunately both were closed without much explanation.

what's your jdk version? it is invaild for jdk8.   BTW, if peon is killed , the data in memory also dropped? @drcrallen

speaking from personal experience, typically you would upgrade it in the very end.

however, router had many bugs which got fixed over time and it appears to work but still considered experimental. at one point there were thoughts of removing it altogether.
router not being mentioned much is due to its unofficial position in the code with no standing whether to really support it in the long term.
given that multiple people use it, so it must be useful and should probably be made a first class citizen.
LGTM after CI, thanks @jon-wei
it would be nice to add a `druid.indexer.runner.endPort` property as well to support the "port range" as suggested in https://github.com/apache/incubator-druid/issues/6154#issuecomment-412286474
you are probably looking for http://druid.io/docs/latest/ingestion/transform-spec.html

@himanshug  In my current design, if `druid.indexer.runner.ports` has been specified and non-empty, ports for one peon process will be chosen from these ports rather than using `druid.indexer.runner.startPort` to allocate ports. So if one user specified `druid.indexer.runner.ports` and `druid.indexer.runner.startPort` at the same time, only property `druid.indexer.runner.ports` will be used. 

Then, if add a `druid.indexer.runner.endPort` property, when one user specified these three properties at the same time, what should be done? I think we should make it clear. IMO, we can add a extra `druid.indexer.runner.portStrategy` property to specify port allocation strategy, whose value can be `range|list|startPort` .

@QiuMM 
1) if `druid.indexer.runner.ports` is provided then only that is used. `start/endPort` are completely ignored.
2) else, start with `startPort` and end at `endPort` , default value of `endPort` would be (-1 or some special value) that would mean infinity.

and we put this precedence information in the documentation so that users know what would happen when all 3 are specified.

@gianm @clintropolis alright, so I have added a new method in `ColumnCapability` . To retain original behavior all STRING, FLOAT, DOUBLE, LONG columns are always filterable , for other (aka COMPLEX) columns filterability can be explicitly set optionally.
`TeamCity` build is failing because `ColumnBuilder.setFilterable(..)` function is unused in Druid code (but used in the my extension). Does anyone know what comments I can add to exclude that method from the check?
`@SuppressWarnings("unused")` I believe
@clintropolis thanks, dint realize it was same as that for intellij... let me add that.
Hmm, I might be confusing it with intellij 😛

If it's not that it's probably 
```
 // noinspection unused
```
?
no, I think you are right ... teamcity is from jetbrains and uses same set of inspections. so I guess it would be same... but the build will confirm soon.

Apparently there is also some race in `KafkaSupervisor`:
```
java.lang.NullPointerException
	at org.apache.druid.indexing.kafka.supervisor.KafkaSupervisor.checkPendingCompletionTasks(KafkaSupervisor.java:1694) ~[classes/:?]
	at org.apache.druid.indexing.kafka.supervisor.KafkaSupervisor.runInternal(KafkaSupervisor.java:902) ~[classes/:?]
	at org.apache.druid.indexing.kafka.supervisor.KafkaSupervisor$RunNotice.handle(KafkaSupervisor.java:614) ~[classes/:?]
	at org.apache.druid.indexing.kafka.supervisor.KafkaSupervisor$2.run(KafkaSupervisor.java:386) [classes/:?]
	at java.util.concurrent.Executors$RunnableAdapter.call(Executors.java:511) [?:1.8.0_162]
	at java.util.concurrent.FutureTask.run(FutureTask.java:266) [?:1.8.0_162]
	at java.util.concurrent.ThreadPoolExecutor.runWorker(ThreadPoolExecutor.java:1149) [?:1.8.0_162]
	at java.util.concurrent.ThreadPoolExecutor$Worker.run(ThreadPoolExecutor.java:624) [?:1.8.0_162]
	at java.lang.Thread.run(Thread.java:748) [?:1.8.0_162]
```

@QiuMM while `65535` is technically correct and largest port number value but I would keep default to be 0 and treat that as infinity. in that way, I don't have to think about technicality of possible port numbers.
